description:
The year is 2040 and the galaxy is flourishing with several colonies and advanced technology. AI is near perfection and the current top idol is the near-completed Virturoid Idol Sharon Apple. All that is missing are her actual feelings, which instead are supplied by Myung Fang Lone. Sharon's debut concert is on planet Eden, where at the same time, fighter pilots Isamu Dyson and Guld Bowman battle over air superiority for the "Supernova Project." Isamu, Guld and Myung were once childhood friends, but after an accident seven years ago, they went their own separate ways. With Myung back in the picture, the old disputes are once again awakened. And when an unstable and illegal AI technique is installed in Sharon, the situation is worsened.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Idol
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of an idol.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Space Opera
tags.description: Centers around space warfare, advanced technology, chivalric romance and adventure.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

node.description:
Kanno's earliest experiences with music came from attending church with her parents. She studied keyboard from a young age on both the piano in her home and the organ at her kindergarten. In elementary school, she began participating in composition contests, but in high school, Kanno began to take more of an interest in literature than in music.

She attended Waseda University, where she majored in literature, but she transcribed music for various student groups at Waseda in her free time. While in university, Koei, a Japanese video game company, asked her to compose the soundtrack to Nobunaga's Ambition. The game turned out to be a hit, and Kanno's music career was launched.

Kanno has also composed music for artists such as [Maaya Sakamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/95090/), [Megumi Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/96105/) and [Kyouko Koizumi](https://anilist.co/staff/164646/). She is also a keyboardist, as well as the frontwoman for [Seatbelts](https://anilist.co/staff/193673/), who perform many of Kanno's compositions and soundtracks.

She has collaborated with directors [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) and [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) multiple times.

In addition to Japanese, she speaks a little English and some French.

Most known for directing critically and commercially successful series, [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) and [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/).

He is noted for blending together multiple genres in his anime. For example, in Cowboy Bebop, classic cowboy western mixes with '60s/'70s New York City film noir, jazz/blues music, Hong Kong action movies, and to top it off the series is set in space. In his later work, Samurai Champloo, he unites the cultures of Okinawa, hip hop, modern-day Japan, and chanbara.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/信本敬子)

Nobumoto made her debut as a scriptwriter in 1989 on TV drama, and on anime two years later with [Fly! Peek the Whale](https://anilist.co/anime/2314/).

Widely known for her work on hit titles such as [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/), [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/) and [Macross Plus](https://anilist.co/anime/474/). She is noted as the original creator of [Wolf’s Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/). She also contributed scripts for [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/), [Space Dandy](https://anilist.co/anime/20057/) and [Carole & Tuesday](https://anilist.co/anime/101281/).

She passed away on December 1, 2021 after a battle with esophageal cancer.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. His projects are usually noted to contain strong themes of love, war, spirituality or mysticism, and ecological concern.

Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Kadutaka_nue)

Kazutaka Miyatake is a visual artist and anime designer known for the mechanical design of the Macross TV series and a number of its continuations from Studio Nue, of which he is a founding member. He has also contributed to the mecha design of other series such as Mobile Suit Gundam SEED Destiny.

Kazutaka Miyatake has designed the spaceships of several famous anime series. His attention to detail and mechanical realism have made his designs still admired upon and used in anime series and related products after several years of their initial appearance.

[Blog](http://blog.a-sha.jp/)

_Note: Not to be confused with the [voice actress](https://anilist.co/staff/236827/)._

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐々木史朗_(音楽プロデューサー%29) | [Flying Dog](https://www.jvcmusic.co.jp/flyingdog/)

The founder of record label [flying DOG](https://anilist.co/studio/464/flying-DOG).

Currently Executive Advisor at [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/Studio-Khara).

After graduating from the Animation Department of Tokyo Designer Gakuin he joned Studio Giants, later working at [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/Gainax) during the production of [Royal Space Force: The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/Royal-Space-Force-The-Wings-of-Honneamise/).

He became a close collaborator of [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/Hideaki-Anno), occupying high positions in all of his productions.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.

Ichirou Itano is a Japanese director, producer, animator and mechanical designer. He has worked in a number of science fiction anime series, especially mecha-themed ones. Director of works such as [Angel Cop](https://anilist.co/anime/1351/), [Battle Royal High School](https://anilist.co/anime/3625/), [Gantz](https://anilist.co/anime/384/) and more.

Itano is best known among anime fans for a style of action scene that he developed, usually nicknamed "Itano Circus" by fans; it refers to a highly stylized and acrobatic method of depicting aerial combat and dogfights in many anime.

The production in [Space Runaway Ideon](https://anilist.co/anime/930/) became a hot topic in the anime industry, and it came to be called this by comparing the brisk movement of mechanics to the air acrobatics of the circus. The technique became more famous when Itano used it for the "dogfights" depicted in [The Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) anime TV series in 1982. It's characterized by detailed, fluid shading of the mecha, the close-range acrobatic moves the dueling fighters make in combat, as well as twisting contrails left by fighters and missiles. It is also commonly used in specific reference to an attack where a mecha or spaceship launches a large swarm of guided missiles with meticulously animated spiraling smoke trails and erratic trajectories and its target is repeatedly dodging those missiles at a high speed.

According to him, [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) and [Yasushi Muraki](https://anilist.co/staff/105090/) are the only animators to have fully mastered Itano Circus.

Shuuichi Kakesu was born 1957 in Chiba Prefecture, Japan. He is a graduate student of Japan Academy of Moving Images and the founder and current representative director of editing studio Jay Film.

He started working at editing studio Okayasu Promotion, where he studied under Okayasu Hajime himself. In 1990 he founded Jay Film; or reorganised Kakesu Henshuushitsu, an editing studio he founded previously, into Jay Film. He was the first to introduce the non-linear editing system in Japan in 1994.

Kakesu won an Association of Media in Digital Award in 1996.

**[SOUND BOX Profile (JP)](http://www.sound-box.jp/information/shizuo_k.html)** | **[SOUND BOX Profile (EN)](http://www.sound-box.jp/english/information/shizuo_k.html)**

Shizuo Kurahashi is a Japanese sound effects editor. He worked as an editor at the Nikkatsu filming studio. After that he started his sound career in ToyoOnkyo. 

He established his own company SOUND BOX in 1988. Since 1983, when the dolby stereo system got popular in Japan - he has been creating filmsounds. He has edited and arranged sounds for over 1000 works.
